message: The 115th Congress convened this week, and following the time-honored tradition of inviting family members to the swearing in ceremony and the Speaker of the House’s address, two of my five grandchildren accompanied me on the House floor.   I am honored to once again serve New Jersey’s Fourth District in the new Congress and will continue to pursue solutions that ensure a better America for all of our children and grandchildren.

The House will soon vote on H. Res. 11, which will repudiate UN Security Council Resolution 2334. President Obama’s decision to abstain and not veto 2334 seriously undermines the peace process, abandons Israel at a critical hour in its life as a nation, and does serious injury to the historical record. By calling on countries to distinguish between the State of Israel and Israeli settlements, 2334 enables the narrative of the anti-Semitic boycott, divestment, and sanctions movement—or BDS movement—that is aimed at delegitimizing Israel.  Moving forward, we must work to align U.S. policy with the consensus of the American people: that we are and remain committed to Israel’s sovereignty and security. Read my full remarks from the House floor: http://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400029

As the US marks Human Trafficking Awareness Day today, we must take the opportunity this spotlight provides to refocus our efforts on ending this horrendous multi-billion dollar industry and modern-day slave trade.  Since 2000, when the Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) was signed into law, more than 120 countries have enacted anti-trafficking laws and many others have taken steps to prosecute these heinous crimes and assist victims—citing the rankings established by the law as a key factor in their efforts.  This Congress, I plan to introduce legislation reauthorizing TVPA. My bill will build on our current foundation while also ensuring our anti-trafficking strategy keeps pace with new research and new ploys by traffickers. http://bit.ly/2eDVtSQ

The Air Force just announced that Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst (JB-MDL) has been selected to host the next generation KC-46 refueling tankers.   Today’s decision is a big win for JB-MDL and a monumental step that will help maintain and secure the base—and its economic impact for New Jersey—for decades to come.  Our delegation has worked hard—with our partners in the State, including the Governor, the Lt. Governor Kim Guadagno, and New Jersey National Guard Adjutant General Michael Cunniff—to highlight the Joint Base’s capabilities and strong record of demonstrating its mission-critical value to national security. The Air Force decision validates what we have said: the Joint Base is and will continue to be a critical asset to the Air Force and America’s ability to respond rapidly to humanitarian or military operations across the globe.
New tanker fleet could help prevent Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst from closing: http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2017/01/new_fleet_of_tankers_to_land_at_njs_joint_base.html#comments
New tanker aircraft will keep Joint Base alive: http://on.app.com/2illAfJ

January is National Birth Defects Prevention Month and this week in particular we also recognize Folic Acid Awareness Week. Studies have shown that Folic Acid, a B-vitamin, is incredibly effective in preventing various birth defects when taken in the months leading up to and in the beginning stages of pregnancy. Specifically, the risk of Spina Bifida can be reduced by up to 70 percent if women of childbearing age consume 400 mcg of folic acid every day, prior to becoming pregnant. http://bit.ly/2irZ3RG

In case you missed it, Rachael Kanapka of Residents Against Giant Electric makes a thorough case against the proposed JCP&L powerline project in Monmouth County.   If approved, the project could place high-voltage “monopoles” through the heart of several neighborhoods, built close to homes, schools and places of worship in Aberdeen, Hazlet, Holmdel, Middletown and Red Bank. Read Rachael’s "Be heard at JCP&L power line hearing" letter on the dangerous impact to the safety and properties of our local community: http://on.app.com/2jkRgUg

Today’s Asbury Park Press editorial opposes JCP&L powerline proposal. Worth a read. “Here’s what we see as the bottom line: The transmission line isn’t needed. Even if it were, it wouldn’t directly benefit the residents living along or near its route — and it could do them and their neighborhoods severe harm. The project should be rejected outright.” http://on.app.com/2koF0kY

Polling consistently shows that a majority of Americans—61% according to a Marist poll released just yesterday—oppose taxpayer funding of abortion, and 8 in 10 Americans think laws can protect both the well-being of a woman and the health of her unborn child.  Because of the Hyde Amendment, two million survivors have had the opportunity to live and enjoy the first and most basic of all human rights—the right to life, while their mothers benefited from prenatal health care and support . Today the House voted 238-183 to pass the bipartisan No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act to make it permanent: http://bit.ly/2kqwMZW

Often mistakenly thought of as a “man’s disease,” heart disease is the #1 cause of death among women—accounting for 1 in 3 deaths each year. Women are also seven times more likely to have a heart attack that is misdiagnosed than men.   Yesterday, I participated in a congressional briefing entitled “Women and Heart Health: A Guide to Staying Heart Healthy” to increase awareness of cardiovascular disease and to urge continued and increased federal support at NIH and CDC for research, as well as programs aimed at surveillance and prevention.   As co-chair of the Congressional Heart & Stroke Coalition, I believe it’s important that we have women in representative numbers in federally funded studies so that we can understand how heart disease presents differently in women; if current diagnostic methods are effective in detecting CVD in women; and if women react similarly to men to different therapeutic treatments.

A recent study indicates that a staggering 73% of all reports of child sex trafficking occur from just a single website—Backpage. The documentary screened on the Hill yesterday, “I am Jane Doe,” showed us in gut-wrenching clarity what happens to the victims posted on these websites. These websites facilitated and promoted child sex trafficking, while individuals profiting from the barbaric practice hid behind confusion in the courts.   My first anti-human trafficking law—Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA)—made it clear that those who knowingly benefit financially from trafficking a child will be held accountable and should be punished to the fullest extent of the law. Make no mistake: websites that ignore a minor in need are complicit in Human Trafficking.    http://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400123

New Jersey has received well over $300 million in federal funding designed to protect our pristine open spaces and wildlife refuges through the Land and Water Conservation Fund, or LWCF. Almost 700,000 sportspersons and 1.7 million wildlife watchers visit wildlife refuges every year, contributing $1.7 billion to the local economy.   Nationally, the outdoor recreation economy supports one out of every twenty American jobs—more than 6 million. These economic benefits are possible because of LWCF which helps direct revenue from oil and gas drilling towards the creation and maintenance of state and federal parks. That is why I have been a long-time supporter of the LWCF and, this week cosponsored H.R. 502—to permanently authorize this critical funding source.

Today, I participated in the official opening of a new state-of-the-art aviation hangar to house a critical Army mission on Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst (JB-MDL): the Communications Electronics Research Development Engineering Center (CERDEC) Flight Activity.  Beginning in February of 2007, my staff and I undertook more than two dozen meetings and significant actions including meeting with then-Defense Secretary Robert Gates, two Secretaries of the Army and the Assistant Secretary of Installations and Environment to ensure two things. First, that CERDEC remained at Lakehurst and not be relocated pursuant to the 2005 BRAC; and second, that a new facility be funded to replace Hangar 5.  CERDEC is a prime example of a mission that has grown and can continue to grow as a result of a coordinated and concerted effort to highlight the talented workforce and other assets—including this new $50 million investment by the Army—that we have at JB-MDL.

The Prevention Coalition of Monmouth County’s critical work in our Congressional District is helping to raise awareness of and prevent prescription drug and other substance abuse—including and especially among teenagers.   In NJ, drug-related deaths increased 53 percent from 2010 to 2012 and approximately two-thirds of all those deaths involved prescription drugs. Further, federal statistics show that overdose deaths from prescription painkillers almost quadrupled between 1999 and 2013 and that opioid abuse is killing nearly 30,000 Americans annually. That’s why I supported the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act, now law, to help struggling communities to address this public health and safety crisis and assist those in need of treatments.

During the national advocacy summit of the Autism Society of America, I was honored to receive the very first “Ignite 4 Autism, Congressional Champion Award.” As co-chair of the Autism Caucus, I stressed the need to build on the enactment of the Autism CARES Act (signed into public law in 2014) by, among other things: passing Kevin and Avonte’s Law, to help law enforcement agencies prevent wandering and locate missing children. It is estimated that 49 percent of the 1 in 68 children nation-wide who have autism have wandered and my legislation will provide targeted support to communities for locally-based, proactive programs that help protect children with developmental disabilities, such as autism, who are prone to wandering.

The NIH estimates it takes 14 years and $2 billion to develop a new drug. This high cost is often a barrier to research, especially when it comes to cures for rare diseases. In fact, an estimated 95% of rare diseases have no FDA approved treatment at all, leaving most of the 30 million afflicted patients with few, if any, options. That’s why I’ve consistently supported robust funding for the NIH and supported the 21st Century Cures Act to reform and streamline the federal research and treatment approval process and incentivize the development of lifesaving cures.   As a member of the Congressional Rare Disease Caucus, and the co-Chair of other critical healthcare caucuses, I am well aware of the benefits of the research conducted at NIH. Not only do these research initiatives save the lives of Americans and mitigate the impact debilitating diseases have on individuals, families and caregivers, funding to prevent and treat diseases will also save money in the long run, as care and services become less expensive and more accessible.

The recent barrage of bomb threats against the American Jewish community must be absolutely condemned and the perpetrators of this hate must be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. Anti-Semitism is a persistent, unique evil and every year for almost 20 years, an overwhelming majority of anti-religious crimes documented in the U.S. have been committed against Jewish Americans.       We cannot wait until bombs threats become bomb blasts. We must have zero tolerance for anti-Semitic hate.

This week I met with many New Jersey veterans, including Fourth District Resident and American Legion member, Darryl Reid, to discuss federal initiatives to support our nation’s veterans. As the former Chairman of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I believe we have a duty and an obligation to repay the debt we owe to those who have fought in defense of our nation and our ideals—I’ll keep working to end veteran homelessness, defend veterans’ education benefits, and ensure accountability on the part of the Department of Veterans Affairs.

Today, the print edition of the APP ran “Ocean Grove thanks those who risked their lives,” a story about a community coming together to thank first responders who risked their lives and to help families displaced by the fire.       Firefighters and first responders, who came from departments in Ocean Grove and surrounding towns to help fight this fire, put their lives on the line to protect our communities, our loved ones and our lives. The important work of fire fighters and first responders was once again underscored for me while surveying the devastation caused by the Ocean Grove fire last Friday with Vito Gadaleta, Business Administrator for Neptune Township.      Thank you to all fire fighters and first responders for their swift action and courage.

As my staff and I mark the 2017 International Women’s Day, it is important to remember that across this country—from world famous soccer players to New Jersey businesswomen—wage discrimination continues to affect millions of women. According to the American Association of University Women, women in New Jersey make 80 cents for every dollar a man makes, and nationally it is even worse.   I am proud to have been one of 193 co-Sponsors on the Paycheck Fairness Act, which enhances the protections and effectiveness of the Equal Pay Pact to help eliminate sex discrimination in the payment of wages, and to have supported the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act.   The original Equal Pay Act was passed by Congress more than 50 years ago; it is long past time to abolish the wage gap. Pay discrimination is gender discrimination.  Pictured: Our dedicated team in the Freehold Constituent Service Center, all of whom are women

This week, the VA announced its plan to expand provisions for urgent mental health needs to former service members with an other-than-honorable (OTH) discharge. 20 veterans take their own lives each day, almost one an hour or over 8,000 per year—more than have been killed in action since 9/11. The incidence of suicide among our veteran population is stunning, tragic beyond words and simply unacceptable.

Today, I voted for, and the House passed, the bipartisan H.R. 1367, a bill that will help the VA to better recruit—and retain—well qualified physicians and other employees.   VA healthcare was one of the many topics I discussed when I met with the NJ VFW last month as we work together to make sure that the care our vets receive is the care that they deserve.

Today I met with Deborah M. Spitalnik, Ph.D., the Executive Director of the Boggs Center on Developmental Disabilities at Rutgers, New Jersey’s first LEND program, and a group of passionate and dedicated LEND trainees to discuss their ongoing efforts to prepare professionals who will work with individuals and families impacted by developmental disabilities.   Last year, I worked with the Association of University Centers on Disabilities to increase federal resources, helping the Boggs Center join 48 other LEND programs—and become New Jersey’s first. Thanks to that provision, the Boggs Center will receive roughly $441k annually over five years to recruit and train additional personnel to better address the needs of individuals with autism and other developmental disabilities.

It was great to meet with Dave Hensal, Jared Stadlin and Thomas Roy from the New Jersey Motor Truck Association yesterday to discuss transportation infrastructure and other issues facing small business owners.   The trucking industry in New Jersey provides 187,430 jobs, or 1 out of every 18 in the state. 84.5% of New Jersey communities rely exclusively on trucking to move goods in and out of town. A strong infrastructure system is critical to ensuring these truckers, along with everyone else on NJ’s roads, can get to their destination safely and as quickly as possible.

According to a recent statement from the IRS, every tax season thousands of people are scammed through fake IRS communication. Even worse, these con-artists often target senior citizens, their families, friends and caregivers. These scammers can sound convincing when they call, using fake names, imminent threats and invented badge ID numbers.  The IRS reminds us that they will never demand immediate payment, threaten to immediately bring in law enforcement or ask for a credit or debit card number over the phone. If you think you are the target of one of these scams, contact the Treasury Inspector General and report the call here: https://www.treasury.gov/tigta/contact_report_scam.shtml or over the phone at (800) 366-4484

This week, I met with the team from the Children’s Home Society of New Jersey and was inspired by our conversation about the positive impact STEM courses and after-school programs have on children’s lives. It is through programs like CHSNJ that many children in New Jersey, and across the country, are empowered to thrive and succeed in an ever-changing world.

For World Autism Awareness Day, my office is participating in the "Light It Up Blue" campaign, to increase understanding and support children with autism and their families. 1 in 41 children in New Jersey, and 1 in 68 children nationally, are on the autism spectrum.   As co-chair and co-founder of the Congressional Autism Caucus, I'm proud to join the thousands of schools, offices, landmarks and the White House in Lighting It Up Blue.

Today marks Equal Pay Day and according to the American Association of University Women, women in New Jersey make 80 cents for every dollar a man makes, and nationally it is even worse. And contrary to myth, it has nothing to do with Education. In fact, according to AAUW, the pay inequality increases from high school graduates (78%) to some college or an associate degree (77%), and increases even further with bachelor’s and advanced degrees (74%).   Pay disparity is real and needs to be fixed. That is why I am glad to announce that I am an original cosponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act of 2017, a step in the right direction, which enhances the protections and effectiveness of the Equal Pay Pact to help eliminate sex discrimination in the payment of wages, and to have supported the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act.

Today, as we mark the 100th anniversary of the United States entry into World War I, let us take a moment to remember the brave and honorable Americans that served our country during this tumultuous time. Over 4.3 million Americans served in the War – 140,000 coming from New Jersey. The toll this war took on mankind is incomprehensible with 116,000 Americans making the ultimate sacrifice in defense of this Nation.  We should remember those Americans who sacrificed so much 100 years ago in the Great War and honor all of those who wear the uniform of our Armed Forces.

The Count Basie Theatre in Red Bank is a treasured landmark poised for future growth. Today, as we viewed the newly renovated theater, I was able to join with Adam Philipson, President & Chief Executive Officer of Count Basie Theatre; Michael Whelan, Red Bank Councilman; Jeremy Grunin, Executive Director of the Jay and Linda Grunin Foundation and Count Basie Theatre Trustee and Maria D. Sorensen, Vice President of Development, Count Basie Theatre to discuss their mission and their outreach to local schools.

I enjoyed meeting with Wendi Silverberg and Bill Cronin of the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network in my Freehold office to discuss supporting cancer research at NIH and the Palliative Care & Hospice Education and Training Act, H.R. 1676, legislation to enhance hospice and palliative care across the country. I am co-sponsoring the bill and look forward to working with them to advance the legislation through Congress.

Al Salazar is a true American hero. During WWII he served honorably in the critical role of “radio man” under Gen. Omar Bradley, and later, Gen. George Patton. He faced what looked like insurmountable odds during the invasion of Normandy and helped ensure the success of the mission.  Mr. Salazar has waited far too long – over 70 years – to receive the proper recognition of his service. Today, it was an honor to be able to present him with his Medals, from both the federal and New Jersey governments, celebrating his outstanding service to our country.

We have great national park sites in New Jersey, including a National Park dedicated to the works of Thomas Edison and the country’s first National Reserve, the New Jersey Pinelands National Preserve, which has more than one million acres of farms, forests, wetlands and communities.  Find something to enjoy during National Parks Week—or anytime! http://www.visitnj.org/article/12-ways-to-enjoy-new-jersey%E2%80%99s-national-parks

The lessons of the Armenian genocide are as relevant as ever – even today as religious and ethnic minorities in the Middle East are being systematically murdered. Let’s speak the truth about past genocide and take action to help the victims and prosecute the perpetrators of today’s genocides.

Thank you to U.S. Army Corp of Engineers’ Lt. Col. Michael Bliss and Lt. Col. Kristen Dahle for the meeting in my D.C. office to further strategize our efforts to mediate Back Bay flooding along New Jersey’s shoreline. The shoreline is an area similar in size to the Everglades -- an expanded, comprehensive and specific study will help ensure that the work is done right the first time.

“Neither Snow Nor Rain Nor Heat Nor Gloom of Night Stays These Couriers From The Swift Completion of Their Appointed Rounds,” the unofficial postal motto carved into the James Farley Post Office in New York, perfectly describes the dedication of our New Jersey Letter Carriers.  It was a pleasure meeting with them this afternoon to discuss postal reform and how Congress can help them get their job done.

ICYMI: NBC News - ‘Frederick Douglass’ Bill Introduced in Congress to Curb Human Trafficking   http://www.nbcnews.com/news/nbcblk/frederick-douglass-bill-introduced-congress-curb-human-trafficking-n752096
It was great to meet with Darren Chell’s GALRE class from Nottingham High School during their tour of the Capitol!

From New Jersey to New Delhi, people all over the world are taking note of World Asthma Day. If you are one of the 1 in 13 Americans with Asthma, the CDC has tools available to create a personalized Asthma Action Plan. Take a look here: https://www.cdc.gov/asthma/actionplan.html

Last night, NJ-04 marked another Congressional Art Competition and I am once again impressed by the immense talent displayed in the entries this year from students in Mercer, Monmouth and Ocean counties.   I am pleased to announce that Tallia Maglione from Wall High School won 2017’s “Best-in-Show” for her spectacular work “The Carousel.” Tallia’s work will be hung in the U.S. Capitol for the next year and all the winners will be recognized at an awards ceremony held in Washington, D.C. later this Spring.

I voted no on the AHCA largely because it cuts Medicaid funding by $839 billion; undercuts essential health benefits such as maternity care, newborn care, hospitalization and pediatric services; includes ‘per capita caps’ and weakens coverage for pre-existing health conditions—all of which will hurt disabled persons (especially and including children and adults with autism), the elderly and the working poor.        Over the past several years, we have seen the flaws of Obamacare, including increased premiums and deductibles, diminishing healthcare options and patients losing plans they were assured they could keep. These very real problems underscore the need for meaningful bipartisan reform.

18 years ago, when I first met now-U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) Chief Warrant Officer Joseph Carlino, I saw his clear dedication to his country and the safety of our waters. Since then he has continued to impress, and I am glad to welcome him back as commander of USCG Station Manasquan Inlet/Shark River. He is taking over from USCG Chief Warrant Officer Chris Sparkman, who has served as the commanding officer of the base for 3 years.  The USCG Station Manasquan Inlet/Shark River is responsible for securing and protecting the shoreline from Spring Lake to Seaside Heights and up to 48 miles offshore. On a typical summer weekend, the Manasquan Inlet has as many as 1,600 boats pass through.

Allaire Community Farm in Wall Township excels at its mission of helping disabled and at risk populations, along with their families, by utilizing their farm and rescue animals to provide innovative and unique job training and therapy.   I enjoyed hearing from founders Sean and Joann Burney how experiences such as therapeutic riding, organic gardening and vocational training help individuals with different physical and cognitive abilities. Individuals who range in age from children to young adults develop increased physical coordination, self-esteem and healthy habits, as well as job skills. There is a particular emphasis on programs for those with autism who are aging out of the education system.

More than ten years ago, President George W. Bush signed the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2005 (P.L. 109-164) into law. The legislation reauthorized the landmark bill, the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000, that I authored and shepherded through Congress in 2000 to create our nation’s anti-human trafficking strategy to go after the perpetrators and help victims, who are mostly women and children. This year I, along with lead Democratic Co-Sponsor Karen Bass, introduced H.R. 2200, the Frederick Douglass Trafficking Victims Prevention and Protection Reauthorization Act, named in honor of the great American abolitionist Frederick Douglass, to reauthorize and strengthen the original law.   The battle against human trafficking must not cease until  there is not a single person held in slavery.

Today, Peace Officers Memorial Day, flags across the U.S. Capitol fly at half-staff to honor those who have made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty. First recognized in 1962, every May 15th people around this great country come together and remember that police officers risk their lives every day to protect us. Thank you to law enforcement—and their families—across the 4th District and the entire state of New Jersey.

When I first met Col. Eric Mellinger in 1982, one of my first nominations to an Academy, it was clear that he would go on to do great things.   Eric proved that intuition correct and rose through the ranks of the Marines, serving as Chief of Staff of the 3rd Marine Expeditionary Force where he spearheaded crucial US relief efforts to a devastated Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan, helping a desperate and shell-shocked people when they needed it most   Today I had the opportunity to meet with Eric again to thank him for his decades of service. Congratulations on your retirement from military service, Eric. Best Wishes for continued success.   Semper Fi!

The InfoAge Museum, formerly US Army Camp Evans, was a secret lab where world-wide wireless communications began, satellite based hurricane tracking was developed and a pre-NASA research team studied the stars, beginning the space age. Located in Wall Township, the museum is now a state-of-the-art facility with 16 buildings over 37 acres offering something for everyone.   This International Museum Day, be sure to take a look at InfoAge or any of the other great museums throughout New Jersey’s 4th District.

Several years ago, I joined with a group to help get the InfoAge Museum off the ground. Since then, it has grown into an amazing historical resource for the people of Central Jersey. This weekend, joined by the New Jersey Color Guard and event organizer Mr. Murphy, I spoke at the museum’s Armed Services and Veterans Appreciation Day about the crucial role servicemembers play in the story of our country.  I commend InfoAge for holding this event and bringing much needed attention to the struggles our vets face every day. As the former Chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, I am acutely aware of the problems that our veterans must overcome as they transition from military to civilian life. That is why I have authored more than a dozen enacted laws—including legislation to aid in education, job training and homelessness benefits—designed to help those men and women who served in uniform.

Over 20 million people—mostly women—suffer from the extreme cruelty of human trafficking. Building on landmark legislation I authored in 2000, the Trafficking Victims Protection Act (P.L. 106-386), I have introduced, along with lead Democratic co-Sponsor Karen Bass of California, the Frederick Douglass Trafficking Victims Prevention and Protection Reauthorization Act of 2017—a $130 million reauthorization package designed to increase efforts to prevent trafficking, protect the victims and prosecute the traffickers.  As we mark anti-human trafficking week, my colleagues in the House and I are taking several additional steps to protect the most vulnerable among us from this horrific practice, passing 8 other legislative proposals designed to prevent children from suffering the horrors of sexual exploitation and ensure justice for traffickers and abusers.

From composers such as Francis Hopkinson and James Lyon, who predate the revolutionary war, to Old Blue Eyes himself, New Jersey has an amazing musical history.  I’m proud to announce that Neptune Township School District lives up to New Jersey’s rich history and received NAMMs “Best Communities for Music Education” award, given in recognition of the school’s commitment to instilling an appreciation for music and helping create the next great generation of New Jersey musicians.

I am glad that I had the opportunity to speak with students from Jackson Liberty High School and Jackson Memorial High School today at the U.S. Capitol for more than 45 minutes to discuss many important issues facing our nation. The students were also interested to learn more about the great opportunity for high school and college students to intern in one of my Congressional offices and better understand how Congress operates.  If you are interested in applying for an internship, please call my Washington D.C. office at (202)225-3765 or Freehold Constituent Service Center at (732)780-3035 for more information.

Today marks Memorial Day in America—one of the most solemn days that we recognize as a country.  It is on this day that we remember those brave and selfless Americans who laid down their lives, and made the ultimate sacrifice in protection of our freedoms. It is only through their actions—and the actions of their brothers and sisters in arms since the first shots of the Battle of Lexington and Concord in the American Revolution—that we enjoy everything in America that we hold dear.
ICYMI: Smith CODEL Meets Famine Victims & US Aid Workers Fighting to Save Lives https://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400387

73 years ago today, 130,000 troops from the U.S., Canada and the U.K. stormed 50 miles of treacherous beaches in Northern France to begin the liberation of Europe from the Nazi regime. To reach their target, they needed to avoid underwater mines, fight through razor wire-covered beaches and attack fortified enemy machine gun positions 120 feet overhead. 4,414 made the ultimate sacrifice in defense of freedom at Normandy that day.  We are all indebted and must never forget what these servicemembers accomplished on that day.

Throughout Syria and Iraq, genocide survivors, Christians, Yazidis and Muslims, are struggling to survive.  Several camps have reported they will run out of food this month. For the few who are able return to their homes and places of business, it is not a warm home coming. Most return to nothing at all, and all too often those who do find their home still standing walk into trip-wire bombs.  Last night, the House took the first step in protecting these survivors by passing my bill, H.R. 390. This afternoon, joined by the lead Democratic co-Sponsor Rep. Anna Eshoo, I called on the Senate to take up this bill as quickly as possible and get these survivors the help they truly need.

Coastal communities across our state depend on a healthy ecosystem for tourism and quality of life as well as commercial and recreational fishing. From Cape May to Sandy Hook, New Jersey has 130 miles of pristine shoreline that we must protect and preserve—now and for the benefit of future generations.  That’s why I’ve once again called on the House appropriators to support NOAA’s National Sea Grant College Program and maintain funding for the BEACH act, a program which has led to the detection of contaminated water off the Jersey Shore and provided over $1 million in federal grants to our state in the last three years.

The Star of Life, a familiar six-pointed star with the rod of Asclepius in the center, is a sign of hope to those who are in need of emergency medical service (EMS) assistance—and the symbol the American Ambulance Association uses on their most prestigious award, the “Stars of Life.”    It was my pleasure to meet with Freehold’s Robert Mazzo, who was recognized as a Star of Life in my Washington office today. Thank you Robert, and all the EMS professionals throughout New Jersey, for the lifesaving work you do.
Please join me in praying for a quick recovery for Steve Scalise, Congressional staff and police who were shot and/or injured today.

Next week, the annual Yulin dog meat festival, where thousands of dogs are tortured and eaten, will once again take place. This event is an awful reminder of the millions of dogs that are killed for food every year in China alone—many of them family pets stolen from back yards, still wearing collars as they arrive at the slaughterhouse. H. Res. 30, which I cosponsored, condemns this barbaric festival and advances the U.S. commitment to animal protection policies.  I have also cosponsored the bipartisan Dog and Cat Meat Trade Prohibition Act of 2017, legislation that will update U.S. laws to further protect these pets.

Today marks the longest day of the year, a day where we reflect on the needs and challenges facing those living with Alzheimer’s disease every day. This is the time to honor the brave individuals who face this disease as well as the caregivers who help them.   As the co-Chair of the bipartisan Alzheimer’s Task Force, I’m proud to join my co-chair, Rep. Waters, in introducing legislation today to provide additional NIH funding for Alzheimer’s research and ensure caregivers have access to the training and resources they need to provide effective care—as we continue work towards prevention, treatment and, hopefully, a cure.

Recently, reports have identified a new scam by individuals claiming to be from the IRS and telling victims two letters were sent to them and were returned as undeliverable. The scammers then demand immediate payment through a prepaid debit card.  The IRS does not demand immediate payment using a specific payment method such as a prepaid debit card, gift card or wire transfer.   To report scam calls, contact the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration through their phone number, (800) 366-4484, or website, http://go.usa.gov/xXBNn.

Congratulations to Mitchell Lauria from Rumson for winning the Congressional Gold Medal! This Eagle Scout’s work will help our towns all along the shore Be Prepared.  If you would like to take a look at his Elevation and Flood Awareness Guide, click here:  http://www.rumsonnj.gov/announcements/borough-of-rumson-local-elevation-and-flood-awareness-guide  In addition to Mitch, Dominic Esposito of New Egypt, Christopher Lauria of Oakhurst and Maya Ravichandran of Holmdel were Gold Medal Winners at this weeks events.

To end hunger worldwide, we must have resources, and we must have the will. It is an honor to work with Bread for the World and the Congressional Hunger Institute, two leading NGOs, that have made an enormous difference in the fight against world wide hunger.

Today, I was grateful to join several WWII Veterans at a dedication ceremony of six breathtaking statues at Bay Lea Park in Toms River. The scope of the battles during WWII, in both theaters of the war, was unprecedented – with bombers and fighter aircraft, colossal aircraft carriers, submarines and newly integrated tactics and strategies.  The six statues unveiled today, which honor soldiers who fought in wars from WWI through Iraq, are everyday reminders to pause, reflect and say a prayer of thanks for those who have sacrificed—and are sacrificing—so much for so many.

June 26th, International Day in Support of Victims of Torture, commemorates the 1987 UN Convention Against Torture and serves as a way to remember and support those who have suffered torture in their lives. Civil rights leaders in Tibet, government reform advocates in Cuba and religious leaders in Vietnam all know the pain of repressive governments using draconian torture methods.   Today also serves as a reminder to those of us in Congress that we must never stop fighting to end this brutal practice. My four torture relief laws, which can be seen here: https://chrissmith.house.gov/legislativeinformation/torturelaws.htm, are a beginning, not an end. Regimes that use these brutal torture methods must be stopped.

This morning, I was honored to be recognized as the House of Representatives recipient of the American Heart Association’s 2017 National Public Service Award.   As the co-chair of the Congressional Heart and Stroke Coalition, a bipartisan, bicameral group of over 100 Members of Congress, I am grateful for the incredible advocates from the AHA for their tireless efforts. I’ll keep working to advance policies to support individuals with cardiovascular disease & increase funding for the critical work done by NIH.

Earlier this week, human rights advocate and Nobel Laurate, Liu Xiaobo—who is gravely ill—was released from his prison cell, but he is not free. The Government of China refuses to even let him visit another city for medical care.   Last night, the House passed my resolution calling on the Chinese government to let Liu leave the country and seek medical care in any country. This action shows that the U.S. Congress stands with Liu, and other proponents of freedom worldwide, exemplified by those who are fighting for freedom in Hong Kong.

Today we celebrate the 241st anniversary of the adoption of the Declaration of Independence, when Members of the Continental Congress, including 5 of our New Jersey delegates, declared that America was a nation unto itself.   As we celebrate today, we must also take a moment to remember the servicemembers—from those serving at the battles of Lexington and Concord to those serving to protect our freedoms today—that have sacrificed so much to uphold that freedom.

Today in Minsk, the OSCE-PA – made up of over 300 lawmakers from 56 countries – overwhelmingly adopted my amendment to help combat anti-Semitism and my resolution to battle online child exploitation and trafficking.   Having worked both domestically and internationally on these two human rights issues, I am encouraged we had such an outpouring of support as we continue to work toward ending these abuses. As the Special Representative on Human Trafficking at the OSCE-PA, I have led the efforts over the years on numerous successful resolutions, enlisting more countries into our fight to protect women and children worldwide.

Great news from the Secretary of Commerce, the NJDEP fisheries plan was found to be in compliance. This decision will help our fishing community, our economy and everyone who visits the shore! Take a look here for more information on my two delegation letters and how this decision will help New Jersey:  https://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400490

It was great to meet Fair Haven’s own Chris Dudick yesterday to see what he was able to do with a National Science Foundation Grant. His business, Small Factory Productions, is creating new and innovative ways for kids and young adults with autism to develop interpersonal skills through virtual visual technology.

Today, the U.S. House will vote on my legislation, the Frederick Douglass Trafficking Victims Prevention and Protection Reauthorization Act (H.R. 2200). This legislation—authorizing more than $500 million over 4 years—will help protect victims of human trafficking and aggressively punish traffickers; and builds on my four previous anti-human trafficking laws including America’s landmark anti-trafficking law, the Trafficking Victims Protection Act. I thank Speaker Ryan, Leader McCarthy and Cathy McMorris Rogers for joining me in prioritizing this critical effort and moving this important legislation to the floor.

Our servicemembers consistently give their all in the defense of our country. Today, the House voted to give them more back. With the passage of the NDAA, which I am proud to have voted for, we are going to give our servicemembers the largest pay raise in 6 years. They deserve it.  This important legislation authorizes $621.5 billion and provides for higher troop levels to ensure our military has the resources and personnel necessary to complete its critical national security and defense missions. Importantly, this NDAA also includes a prohibition on another Base Realignment and Closure (BRAC), adding another layer of protection for the mission critical work conducted by the top notch men and women at JB-MDL.

It was great to see the Carver family, who received a tour of the U.S. Capitol from my office. Did you know that more than 2,300 residents of New Jersey’s 4th Congressional District have received tours through my office in 2017? If you would like to visit the Capitol, or any of the other attractions in our nation’s capital, please contact Angela in my Washington D.C. office at (202) 225-3765.
Senator McCain has the faith, grit and determination to overcome this serious challenge. The Congress—the country—honors his extraordinary service and prays he will be back soon.

Blood donations always drop in the summer, but this year supplies are near critical levels. For any and all who are able, please consider visiting your closest blood collection center and donate. A single donation could save up to three lives and most donation clinics accept walk-ins.

There are less than two days until the start of the 2017 Congressional App Challenge—which runs until November 1st and is open to all students K-12th grade. If you, or someone you know, has an idea for an App, please reach out to my Freehold Constituent Service Center at (732) 780-3035 or visit congressionalappchallenge.us for more information.
House Passes Bill to Sanction Iran, Russia and North Korea

Throughout our country, too many people are the victims of what SADD (Students Against Destructive Decisions) call the four Ds, driving while: Drowsy, Drugged, Distracted or Drunk. It was great to hear from Kristen, Riya, Brianna and Dylan—four Monmouth County High Schoolers—about our school aged citizens who are working to help their peers get home safe.   Look forward to working further with these leaders on policy initiatives to help enhance safety on the road.

40 residents from across New Jersey’s 4th District joined with me yesterday at Capitol Hill's annual Monarch Housing event to defend affordable housing options, to protect Medicaid from harmful rollbacks and to give a voice to our nation’s homeless veterans.

Veterans who served in the Global War on Terrorism have—and continue—to give so much to protect our freedoms here at home. I am proud to have co-sponsored, and helped pass, the “Global War on Terrorism War Memorial Act” (HR 873).   This legislation will allow the Global War on Terror Memorial Foundation to build a commemorative work on federal land, similar to works that honor veterans from other campaigns.

I was honored to join Brigadier General Cunniff, an amazing group of servicemembers and community leaders in marking the opening of Sea Girt’s new state-of-the-art training facility at their ribbon cutting ceremony. This institute couldn’t come at a more important and critical time in our history—training is what wins warns, preserves the peace and mitigates casualties.   I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress to rebuild our military and enhance combat readiness.   I thank Brigadier General Cunniff for his kind words, “First and foremost, I would like to recognize and thank Congressman Chris Smith for his leadership and commitment to the wellbeing of the armed forces and his dedication to making this project possible to ensure our troops have the best equipment and facilities.”

First responders in Texas—like in New Jersey during Superstorm Sandy—are heroically saving the lives of thousands of people trapped by massive flooding from Harvey. They are heroes, risking their lives to save others.     The federal government, working in partnership with state and local authorities, must provide immediate resources and expertise for rescue and to ensure recovery and resilience. Years after Superstorm Sandy, New Jersey knows all too well the deadly and long-lasting impact of natural disasters.    The outpouring of relief efforts by individuals and organizations demonstrate the ability of Americans to unite in the face of crisis and urgent need.

Today, National POW/MIA Recognition Day, we pay special tribute to the American heroes who were taken prisoner or who remain missing. All our men and women in uniform have, and continue, to give so much—we owe them an immeasurable debt.    To our POW/MIAs and their families: You Are Not Forgotten.

Great groundbreaking at the Count Basie Theatre today. ICYMI, here is the APP story: http://www.app.com/story/entertainment/music/2017/09/20/count-basie-theatre-breaks-ground-23-million-expansion/684436001/

Today, the House passed, with my strong support, a disaster relief bill with over $18 billion in urgently needed funding for FEMA’s Disaster Relief Fund to aid victims of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria. This funding will go to life-saving missions, infrastructure repair, funding municipal services and financial assistance to survivors.    Of note, the bill also includes over $1 billion in disaster supplemental nutrition assistance for Puerto Rico in this time of grave humanitarian crisis. In addition to supporting this added disaster relief funding, just days after Maria’s landfall, I joined my colleagues in urging the Administration to immediately deploy all available federal assets to Puerto Rico to reestablish telecommunications services and critical infrastructure on the island and recently met with DOD officials to discuss their response in Puerto Rico. It is encouraging to know that servicemembers from JB MDL are part of the ongoing DOD mission to aid Puerto Rico.   Today’s bill will provide meaningful short term relief to the suffering people of Puerto Rico, but more should and will be done to assist our fellow Americans in their time of need.

Participated this morning in groundbreaking for the much-needed roadway improvement project at the high-volume intersection of Routes 34 and CR 537 in Colts Neck. Project includes $17.5 million in federal funding to ease traffic jams and increase safety at the busy, and at times dangerous, intersection. Construction plans include bridges on each side of the roadway. Special thanks to Freeholder Director Lillian Burry for her tenacious leadership over the past 17 years to make this project a reality.

Thanks to the thousands who came out in the rain today in Bradley Beach for the 2017 Walk to End Alzheimer's. Cutting that ribbon alongside advocates and supporters was an honor!    As co-founder and chairman of the congressional Alzheimer’s caucus since 2000, I am pleased to report that we have tripled Alzheimer’s research dollars from just under $600 million in 2015 to $1.8 billion in 2018. That investment in research is reason for serious hope for patients and their caregivers—who are typically family members—that we will continue to improve treatments and someday soon find a cure for the 5 million people in the United States who suffer from Alzheimer’s disease.

5 million people in the U.S. suffer from Alzheimer’s disease, and countless million family members and caregivers are affected each and every day.  That’s why I was proud to raise  awareness this morning to #ENDALZ on @NJ1015 with Bill Spadea @AlzAssnGNJ #WalkToEndAlz.    Click the link below to listen:

I was proud to honor Spring Lake Heights Police Sgt. Andy O'Neill last night for his actions that saved the life of a father of two in June.  Andy, a 28-year police veteran, won the 2017 Workwear MVP award from ServiceWear Apparel, after being one of 50 nominees for the award from across the country.   On Father's Day, he wasn't scheduled to work, but instead he let another father with a newborn son have the day off to be home with his family. On the job that day, Andy's prompt and effective response to a victim of cardiac arrest saved the life of a local father of two daughters.   Below are my remarks upon presenting Andy with the award:  "The Talmud says 'whoever saves one life, saves the entire world.'   Every life is precious, unique and irreplaceable.   So it is especially fitting that Sgt. Andy O’Neill has won the 2017 National MVP award for his skill and decisions in saving a man’s life.   It took a team, but that team, that day had an extraordinary leader. And the man whose heart had stopped is here tonight.   Sgt. O’Neill wasn’t supposed to be on the job that day, having selflessly given up his Father’s Day for another dad with a new son.   I wish we could package that kind of goodness.   Thank you Andy – and every police officer – for making our community safer.   For being the single most important deterrent to crime in all of its ugly manifestations.   For doing the dangerous job of apprehending and bringing criminals to justice.   For your critical role in emergencies and natural disasters.   And special thanks to your families for the sacrifice you made."

After nearly a year of negotiations with high-ranking officials of the United States Navy, the Pentagon has told me they are cancelling plans to open housing on NWS Earle, thereby alleviating legitimate local concerns about security, and the proper vetting of nonmilitary renters who would be exempt from paying property taxes.  For more, click here: https://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400684

Today I chaired a briefing on international child abduction. The State Department estimates that 700-1,000 children per year are abducted out of the U.S. by one parent, against the wishes of the other parent or without permission from a court.   Although the Hague Convention set up a legal avenue for bringing about the safe return of children unlawfully abducted into another country, it lacked sufficient enforcement. Some countries don't abide by the agreement, or their courts may take years to settle cases of abduction -- years of a child's life gone.   Survivor Leo Zagaris, who was abducted to Greece by his father when he was 10, testified on Friday that he could have been home in weeks if the courts moved more quickly. He was gone for two years.   I introduced the Sean and David Goldman International Child Abduction Prevention and Return Act, which was signed into law in 2014. It gave the State Department tools to enforce the international agreement against child abduction and hold countries accountable.   Alissa Zagaris, mother of Leo Zagaris, testified that strict penalties, like criminal charges, when properly applied, can be an effective deterrent against child abduction. "Taking parents take because they feel they can get away with it,” she said.   For more on the briefing, click here:   https://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400691

On the fifth anniversary of Superstorm Sandy hitting New Jersey, I remember all the victims of the storm that destroyed thousands of homes and businesses and killed more than 100 people on the East Coast. The recovery still continues today.   Over the weekend, I visited some areas in Monmouth and Ocean Counties that were among those hardest-hit by the storm, including a dune area slated for improvement and the site of a house destroyed in the storm that is still being rebuilt.   Faith leaders, whose churches provided aid in the wake of the storm, shared their powerful stories of service and rebuilding after the disaster. I also met with local officials, led by Mayor Stephen Reid, at Point Pleasant Beach.   My bill, the Federal Disaster Assistance Nonprofit Fairness Act, would allow houses of worship -- which suffered damage from the storm but helped greatly in the recovery effort after Sandy -- equal access to federal disaster assistance. Many area churches, synagogues, and other religious organizations were not eligible for such aid in the wake of Sandy, due to their religious status.  The bill passed through the House in 2013 with bipartisan support but stalled in the Senate. I have reintroduced it in the House as HR 2405, and it has bipartisan support.

Property and state income taxes in my district -- and New Jersey -- are unconscionably high and especially harm the middle class. The tax reform proposal as currently written is unacceptable. I will continue to fight to protect the state and local tax deduction (SALT).

Yesterday, I spoke at a solemn ceremony opening the “Journeys Beyond Genocide: The Human Experience” exhibit at Brookdale Community College in Lincroft, which remembers -- and honors -- the victims and survivors of three different genocides.  This sobering exhibit features powerful testimonies and archival items of local genocide survivors from the Holocaust, the Armenian Genocide, and the 1994 Rwandan genocide.   It is part of the crucial work by the Center for Holocaust, Human Rights & Genocide Education at Brookdale to educate future generations about genocide – the “crime of crimes” which still occurs today due to the silence of many. The promise of the genocide convention – “never again” -- remains unfulfilled. The convention’s goals were to prevent and punish genocide.  We have failed, and we need to do more.  It is my hope that exhibits like this one will educate and hopefully sensitize more and more people, including our young people, to realize that we must all speak out to ensure that “never again” becomes reality.  To read more on the event, click here: https://chrissmith.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=400738

While I believe Americans are overtaxed and need relief, I must vote “no” this week on the tax bill, H.R. 1, because of its negative impact on both New Jersey and my congressional district.     Almost half – 47% ‒ of the taxpayers in my district itemize, claiming an average of $31,981 in deductions.   The elimination – even modification – of the state and local tax deduction (SALT) will significantly increase taxes for many. That’s unacceptable, and reason enough to oppose the legislation. Making matters worse are other provisions in the legislation that nullify or significantly scale back numerous well-crafted deductions including the medical deduction – utilized by 40,000 taxpayers in my district, largely the elderly and disabled, with an average deduction of $9,254 – as well as deductions for student loans, education, property damage, and mortgages, among others.

Congratulations to the winners of the Fourth Congressional District’s 2017 Congressional App Challenge (CAC): Luke Boylan, Theresa Cardone, Jaspreet Kaur, and Adrian Wittmann, of Point Pleasant Borough High School, and their teacher, Mr. Nick Gattuso.   These talented students showed their collective creativity in designing the “Lunch Buddy App” to help students in the Life Skills class socialize with peers and build camaraderie during lunch. They won a $250 credit from Amazon Web Service. Their winning app will be featured at the House of Code reception on Capitol Hill this spring and will be displayed in the Capitol Building for a year.  Special thanks to the three judges who answered the call when I tapped them to participate in the challenge, reviewing all entries and selecting the winners.   I also want to also acknowledge the students from Monmouth County’s Communications High School: Matthew Avena of Red Bank, Daniel Kimball of Middletown, and Ronan Leahy of Colts Neck, who received Honorable Mention for their app “Ugo!” which is designed to help provide kids with information on recreational and volunteer events outside their home.    Around the world, the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) fields are central to the global workforces of the future, and our nation must strive to be a leader here for economic growth and innovation. This challenge was created precisely to meet this need and help foster this growth.
